Also, don't touch your face, wear a ball cap or headphones on camera. Professionalism will get my sub. Stopped watching when you said you'd shut up  but didn't.

44:56 That looks to be an amazingly accurate landing! Looks like about two metres off centre. If Space X can do that time after time on a seriously heaving barge on the ocean, they should be able to land the "BFR" booster on its very fixed launch pad (I would expect a precision of centimetres being needed). Whereas the Falcon 9 first stage has a dry may of around 20 tons, we can expect the BFR first stage to be over 100 tons. The Saturn V first stage weighed about 130 tons, but its engines had a low thrust to weight ratio and composites were not widely used in those days, but BFR will need to be more robust to withstand re-entry and re-use.

Tim, as a fellow academic I appreciate so much your dedication to putting up quality, in-depth, fact-checked information videos. I started working at an academic project in history of science (we both started with same level of non-expertise). First lesson: don't state anything academically that isn't probative. Once a "fact" is out there, it can be quoted and re-quoted and propagate, so it better be right. Your work/produced vids sounds right to me. (If curious- darwin.amnh.org .)
